sections.doco:title: Pairings in local fields and cryptography
sections.doco:abstract: In this paper we present the results on the problem of explicit reciprocity law, as in the classical part of the field of algebraic numbers and their generalization to multidimensional fields and formal groups. The result is an explicit formula in the circular extension of the field of $p$-adic numbers is applied to the determination of a new public-key cryptosystems and electronic signatures.
sections.doco:subtitle: Pairings in local fields and cryptography
sections.doco:keywords: Reciprocity laws, multidimentional local fields, formal groups, explecet pairing in reciprocity law, $p$-adic numbers, number fields, local fields, public key cryptosystem, e-signature
sections.doco:introduction:
We consider local pairings arised in the classical reciprocity laws
at the turn of the 20th century and define a new cryptosystem and an
electronic signature. In part 1, we define pairings and review some
basic results in this area. In part 2, we describe and study pairing
based cryptosystems and   electronic signatures.
sections.doco:conclusion:
%\begin{center}%\textbf{Conclusion}%\end{center}
In the present paper, we suggest an approach to constructing
asymmetric encryption systems based on bilinear pairings on groups.
A computationally hard problem in these systems is the discrete
logarithm problem, which can be seen from the description of  the
ciphering and deciphering in the systems presented in the preceding
section. Let $r$ be a given ciphertext obtained by encryption of a
text $M$ in the system  1) or 2), $ r = a^M \mod{m^2} $ or $ r =
a^M \mod{N^m}. $ Then an attack of the first type against these
systems is a search for a solution of the discrete logarithm
problem, $ M = \log_ar. $ Consequently, we have reasons to believe
that choosing groups $G_1$ and $G_2$ for which there is a pairing
such that  there are no effective algorithms in $G_2$ for finding
the discrete logarithm, we obtain cryptosystems with more effective
key sizes than RSA or ElGamal. A search for such groups is of
considerable interest for cryptography. A more serious
cryptoanalysis also needed because the  proposed cryptosystem is
based on the Wieferich numbers not previously used in cryptography.
Subsequently, it will be required to search for specific attacks
against these systems, which could either simplify the solution of
the discrete logarithm problem or to verify their absence.

The authors are grateful to Nikolai Osipov (Institute of Space and
Information Technologies of the Siberian Federal University
(Krasnoyarsk)) for their interest and valuable comments.

%\begin{center}%\textbf{\textsection 1. Pairings}%\end{center}$1^0.$ Pairings in number fields considered in the present paper
first appeared when David Hilbert began to develop Kronecker's idea
concerning an analogy between numbers and functions (for more
details about this analogy, see the book [1]).

Hilbert applied this idea to a long-standing problem on the
reciprocity law, which consisted in finding an explicit expression
for the product of $n$th power residue symbols in a number field
containing all $n$th roots of  1,
$$
\left(\frac{\alpha}{\beta}\right)_n \left(\frac{\beta}{\alpha}\right)_n^{-1} = \zeta_n^{f(\alpha, \beta)},
$$
i.e., in the calculation of the function $f(\alpha, \beta) \in
\mathbb{Z} \mod n\mathbb{Z}$(for details, see, e.g., [2]). In his
9th problem, D. Hilbert suggested to extend the calculations from
number fields to the fields of $p$-adic numbers, i.e. from global
fields to local fields in the terminology of  Serre. In other words,
to make these calculations local,  which in essense is an analog of
the calculation of the Abelian integral of a differential form on a
Riemann surface in terms of residues (see [3], p. 114)).

An analog of the residue of a differential form in a local field is
the norm residue symbol defined by Hilbert (the Hilbert symbol)
$\left(\frac{\alpha,\beta}{\rho}\right)_n$ defined in a $p$-adic
(local) field containing all $n$th roots of 1. The definition of
Hilbert's symbol can be found in many sources (see, e.g., [4]).
Class field theory connects the product of power residues with the
product of local symbols (see Hasse [2]):
$
\left(\frac{\alpha}{\beta}\right)_n\left(\frac{\beta}{\alpha}\right)^{-1}_n
= \prod\limits_{\rho|n\infty}\left(\frac{\alpha,
\beta}{\rho}\right)_n.
$
We will present an explicit formula for the norm residue symbol
first obtained in the papers [4] -- [6]; this formula shows
more clearly an analogy between this symbol and the residue of a
differential form at a singular point.

Let $K$ be a local field (a finite extesion of $\mathbb{Q}_p$)
containing a primitive $p^n$th root $\zeta$ of $1$. Let $\pi$ be a
prime element of $K$, let $\mathfrak{o}$ be the ring of integers of
the inertia subfield $T$ of the extesion $K/\mathbb{Q}_p$, and let
$\tr:=\tr_{T/\mathbb{Q}_p}$ be the trace operator. For an element
$\alpha \not= 0$, we denote by
$\underline{\alpha}:=\underline{\alpha}(x)$ an arbitrary series in
$\mathfrak{o}((x))^*$ such that $\underline{\alpha}(\pi) = \alpha$.
Let $\Delta $ be the Frobenius automorphism in
$\mathfrak{o}/\mathbb{Z}_p$; by the same letter, we denote the
Frobenius operator on the Loran series ring $\mathfrak{o}((x)),$$
f(x)^{\Delta} = (\Sigma a_ix^i)^{\Delta} = \Sigma a^{\Delta}_ix^{pi}
$ We define a function $l$ on the group $\mathfrak{o}((x))^*$ of
invertible series with values in the additive group of the power
series ring $\mathfrak{o}[[x]]$, $ l:\mathfrak{o}((x))^*
\longrightarrow \mathfrak{o}[[x]], $ as follows:

\begin{equation}
l(f) = \frac{1}{p}\log f^p/f^{\Delta}, f \in \mathfrak{o}((x))^*
\end{equation}(see [4], \textsection 1). For arbitrary elements $\alpha,  \beta\in
K^*$ and the corresponding series $\underline{\alpha},
\underline{\beta}\in \mathfrak{o}((x))^*$, we consider the series
%\begin{equation}$
\Phi(\alpha, \beta) = l(\underline{\alpha})dl(\underline{\beta})  -
l(\underline{\alpha})\underline{\beta}^{-1}d\underline{\beta} +
l(\underline{\beta})\underline{\alpha}^{-1}d\underline{\alpha},
%\end{equation}
$
where $d:=\frac{d}{dx}$(see [4], \textsection 2). Then, for
$p\not=2$, we obtain the following explicit formula for the Hilbert
symbol:
\begin{equation}
(\alpha, \beta) = \zeta^{\tr \res_x\Phi(\alpha, \beta)/s(x)},
\end{equation}
where $s(x)=(\underline{\zeta}^{p^n}-1)^{-1}$ if the first coefficients of
 $\underline{\alpha}$ and  $ \underline{\beta}$ belong to the Teichm\"{u}ller
 system $\mathcal{R}$ and  $s(x) = (\underline{\zeta}^{p^n}-1)^{-1} + 1/2$ in the general case (see [7], \textsection 6).

{\bf Remark}. The    series $\Phi(\alpha, \beta)$ is an analog of a
differential form. Therefore, the norm residue symbol ( , ) is an
analog of the residue of the differential form $\Phi(\alpha, \beta)$
at the ``singular point'' $\underline{\zeta}^{p^n}-1$ since
$\zeta^{p^n} - 1 = 0$.

Formula (2) can be obtain in two essentially different ways; both
rely on unramified extensions as the core of class field theory. In
the case of Kummer extensions, where the $n$th roots of 1 belong to
the ground field, the unramified extensions are given by the
so-called primary elements.We recall that an element $\omega$ of a
local field $K$ containing all $n$th roots of $1$ is called
$n$-primary (or primary) if the extension $K(\sqrt[n]{\omega})/K$ is
unramified. Thus, to derive formula (2), we must calculate the
$p^n$-primary elements in $K$ explicitly. An arbitrary primary
element was first calculated in the paper [4], $\textsection 4$; it
has the form $ \omega(a) = E(a(\underline{\zeta}^{p^n}-1))|_{x =
\pi},~~~~~~~~ a \in \mathfrak{o}, $ and, for the Hilbert symbol, we
have the equation
%\begin{equation}$
(\pi, \omega(a)) = \zeta^{\tr a},
$%\end{equation}
valid for an arbitrary prime element $\pi$.

The first method of deriving formula (2) is as follows. First, using
the Eisenstein relation $(x, x-1) = 1$, $x\not=0,1$(in $K$-theory
this relation is called the Steiberg relation), we reduce the
calculation of $(\alpha, \beta)$ for arbitrary elements $\alpha,
\beta\in K^*$ to the calculation of $(\pi, \varepsilon)$, where
$\varepsilon $ is a principal unit in $K$. Now, knowing all primary
elements explicitly and using the decomposition of $\varepsilon$
into the product $ \varepsilon =  \prod\limits_{\theta, p \nmid
i}(1-\theta \pi^i)^{a_{\theta, i}}\omega(a_{\varepsilon}), ~~~
a_{\theta, i} \in \mathbb{Z}_p, $ where $\theta$ runs over the
Teichm\"{u}ller system $\mathcal{R}$, we calculate the symbol $(\pi,
\varepsilon)$. Here we again take into account the Eisenstein
relation, which implies the relation $(\pi, 1 - \theta \pi^i) = 1$
for $(i, p) = 1$. Hence, by (3), we obtain $ (\pi, \varepsilon) =
\zeta^{\tr a_{\varepsilon}} $.  For details, see [4], [8],  and
sections  1 and 2 in [9].

The second way of deriving formula (2) is based on the explicit
construction of the pairing
%\begin{equation}$
< , >: K^*\times K^* \longrightarrow \mu_{p^n}
%\end{equation}
$ given by (2).

 We must check that the pairing is well defined, i.e.,
that the following properties are valid: the invariance under the
choice of a prime element and the independence of an expansions of
the elements of $K^*$ in powers of the prime. Next we must check the
basic property of the pairing, i.e.,
$$
<\alpha, \beta> = 1 \Leftrightarrow \alpha \; \text{is a norm in the extension}\; K\left(\sqrt[p^n]{\beta}\right),
$$
and, finally, we must check that the pairing $< , >$ coincides with
the Hilbert symbol.

This plan was implemented in the paper [4]. The second way is more
interesting because the pairing $< , >$ can be used to explicitly
construct
 class field theory for Kummer extensions, which is an analog of the theory of vector spaces with scalar product.
 This one more time emphasizes the idea of a deep analogy between numbers and functions.  The result is as follows ([4],  \S 7).

Let $A  $ be a subgroup of finite index in $K^{*}$ containing
$K^{*p^n}$  and let $B = A^{\perp}$ be the orthogonal complement of
$A$ with respect to the scalar product $< , >$. Then $B$ is the
group of norms of the extension $K(\sqrt[p^n]{A})/K,$$Nm_{L/K}L^* = B$,  where $L = K(\sqrt[p^n]{A}).$
 An approach to the derivation of explicit formulas based on the field of norms is suggested in [10].

$2^0.$ In the late 70th, K. Kato and A. Parshin motivated by the
needs of algebraic geometry constructed the theory of
multidimensional complete fields based on $K$-theory (see [11] --
[13]).

We give the definition of a multidimensional complete field. Let $K$
be a complete discrete valuation field with a perfect residue field
$ k$ of characteristic  $p>0$. We call such a field a
one-dimensional complete field and its residue field $k$ a
zero-dimensional complete field.

\begin{defenition}   A field $K$ is called an  $n$-dimensional
complete field if $K$ is complete with respect to a discrete valuation and the residue field $\overline{K}$ of $K$ is an $(n-1)$-dimensional complete field.
\end{defenition}
Putting $K=K_n$ and $\overline{K}=K_{n-1}$, we obtain the sequence
of fields
$
k=K_0, K_1, \dots, K_{n-1}, K_n=K
$
in which $K_{i-1}$ is the residue field of the complete discrete valuation field $K_i, i \geq 1$.
\begin{defenition}
We say that a complete $n$-dimensional field $K$ is
equal-characteristic if $\cha~K = \cha k$, is
distinct-characteristic if $\cha K=0, \cha K_{n-1}=p>0$, and is
mixed-characteristic if $\cha K=\dots=\cha K_s=0$, $\cha
K_{s-1}=p>0, s\geq 1.$
\end{defenition}
The Loran series field $\mathbb{F}_p((u))((t))$ gives an example of
an equal-characteristic field. The Loran series field
$\mathbb{Q}_p((t))$ is a mixed-characteristic two-dimensional field.
The field of infinite in both directions Loran series $ K =
\mathbb{Q}_p\{\{t\}\} = {\sum\limits_{i=-\infty}^{\infty}a_it^i, a_i
\in \mathbb{Q}_p}, $ where $a_i \to 0~ \text{as}~ i \to -\infty$ and
the set of coefficients is bounded from below in the norm of the
field $\mathbb{Q}_p$, gives an example of a distinct-characteristic
two-dimensional field since $\cha K = 0,~ \cha \overline{K}=p$,
where $\overline{K} = \mathbb{F}_p((t)).$
The definition of the Hilbert symbol in the multidimensional field
is based on the reciprocity map. In the case of a
distinct-characteristic multidimensional field $K$, we define the
reciprocity map as follows:
$
\psi: K_n^{top}(K) \to Gal(K^{ab}/K),
$
where $K_n^{top}$ is Milnor's topological $K$-group equipped with the Parshin topology (see [13]). We assume that the field $K$ contains the group $\mu_m$ of $m$th roots of 1. Then the Hilbert symbol is defined as follows:
$$
(~,~): K_n^{top}(K)\times K^* \to \mu_m, \quad  (\{\alpha_1, \dots,
\alpha_n\}, \beta)=\sqrt[m]{\beta}^{\psi(\{\alpha_1, \dots,
\alpha_n\})-1}.
$$
In an arbitrary complete multidimensional field, the definition is
more involved. For details, see the paper [14].

In a distinct-characteristic multidimensional local field with
finite last residue field,  an explicit formula for the Hilbert
symbol and constructive class field theory is obtained in the paper
[15]. For the general complete multidimensional field the result is
obtained in the papers  [16] and [17](see also [18] and [19]).

$3^0.$ Now, we turn to the generalization of the reciprocity law to
the formal modules. This generalization is motivated by the needs of
algebraic geometry and is used, for example, in the theory of
elliptic curves. The formal group laws first were defined by Bochner
in 1946 in connection with the theory of real and complex of Lie
groups, for which the group operation in the vicinity of 1 is
defined by a tuple  of convergent power series satisfting certain
relations following from the group axioms. Bochner suggested to
regard such a tuple per se regardless the convergence. The Lie
algebra of the given Lie group is determined by this tuple of formal
series. In this way we obtain  new objects intermediate between Lie
groups and Lie algebras and called formal group laws. Formal group
laws arise in many other situations; e.g., an arbitrary Dirichlet
series
$
L(s, \chi) = \sum\limits_{n \geq 1} \chi(n)n^{-s},
$
where $\chi$ is the Dirichlet character modulo $n$ admitting the Euler expansion gives rise to
 a one-dimensional formal group law. Such formal group laws arise naturally in the complex oriented cohomology theory.
 The addition of points on an elliptic curve is defined by a regular function, and in terms of a local parameter in a
  neighborhood of zero the addition is given by a formal series in two variables satisfying natural conditions following
   from group identities. Thus, an elliptic curve yields a formal group law.

\begin{defenition}
A one-dimensional formal group law (or, simply, a one-dimensional
formal group) over a ring $R$ is a series $F(X, Y) \in R[[X, Y]] $
satisfying the conditions 1. $F(X, F(Y, Z)) = F(F(X, Y), Z) $
(associativity); 2. $F(X, 0) = X$, $ F(0, Y)=X$ (for details, see
[20]).
\end{defenition}
We have the following important classes of formal groups: 1. The
Lubin--Tate formal groups; 2. The relative Lubin--Tate formal
groups; 3. The Honda formal groups; 4. The polynomial formal groups.

The distinguishing feature of the first three types of formal groups
is that the endomorphism ring of the formal group is isomorphic
either to the ring over which the formal group is defined (the
Lubin--Tate formal groups) or is an unramified subextension of this
ring. The polynomial formal groups have the form $X+Y+aXY$;  they
are the only formal group laws given by polynomials and have the
property that the ring over which the group is defined (i.e., a ring
containing the element $a$) can be an arbitrary extension of the
endomorphism ring isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_p$.

The Lubin--Tate formal groups  first arised   in the  paper $[21]$
for an explicit construction of Abelian extensions (see [22]) in
local class field theory. The relative Lubin--Tate formal groups
were applied to the study of metabelian $p$-extensions of local
fields (see [23]). The Honda formal groups are important primarily
because they give all formal groups over the ring of Witt vectors
(see [24]). The polynomial formal groups are used, in particular, in
the study of quadratic extensions of number fields (for details, see
[24]).

We define the Hilbert pairing on formal modules in a local field.
Let $К$ be a local field, and let $F(X, Y)$ be a formal group
defined over the ring of integers of $K$. Let $\mathfrak{o}$ be the
endomorphism ring and  $\pi$ be a prime element of $\mathfrak{o}$.


We consider an extension $L$ of $K$ containing the kernel of the
isogeny $[\pi^n]_F$, $\Ker[\pi^n]_F\subset L$. Let $\mathfrak{M}$ be
the maximal ideal in  $L$. We define the structure of a formal
module on  $\mathfrak{M}$ by putting $ \alpha + _F\beta = F(\alpha,
\beta)~ \text{for}~ \alpha, \beta \in \mathfrak{M},
$
and denote the module obtained by $F(\mathfrak{M})$. It is clear that  $\Ker[\pi^n]_F \subset F(\mathfrak{M})$. Let, as before,
$
\psi: L^* \longrightarrow Gal(L^{ab}/L)
$
be the reciprocity map of  $L$. Then the Hilbert symbol is defined as follows:
$$
(~,~)_{F, n}: L^* \times F(\mathfrak{M}) \longrightarrow
\Ker[\pi^n]_F,
%$$
%$$
\quad (\alpha, \beta)_{F, n} =
\left(\frac{1}{[\pi^n]_F}(\beta)\right)^{\psi} -
_F\left(\frac{1}{[\pi^n]_F}(\beta)\right),
$$
where $\gamma = \frac{1}{[\pi^n]_F}(\beta) $ is a root of the
equation $[\pi^n]_F(X)=\beta$ in the algebraic closure.

The first explicit formulas were obtained for the Lubin --Tate
formal groups (see [25], [26]). For the Lubin--Tate relative formal
groups, explicit formulas were obtained in [27] and, for the Honda
formal groups,
 in [28] -- [32]. Explicit formulas for the polynomial formal groups were obtained in  [33] in the unramified case and in  [34] in the general case.

$4^0.$ For the methods of cryptography considered in part 2 of the
present paper, we use a very particular case of the multiplicative
pairing (2) in the cyclotomic field $\mathbb{Q}_p(\xi)$, where $\xi$
is a primitive $p$th root of 1; namely, we use the pairing $ <~,~>:
<\pi> \times \mathbb{Z}_p^* \to \mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$, $ <\pi, a>
= \res_Xx^{-1}l(a)(x^{_p}+ \frac{1}{2}),
$
where the function $l$ is defined in (1). For applications in cryptography it is convenient to define this pairing in the form
$$
<~,~>: \mathbb{Z}^{(p)} \times \mathbb N^+\to
\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}, \quad  <n, a> = l(n)a \pmod p
$$
where $\mathbb{Z}^{(p)}$ is the monoid of positive integers prime to $p$.

%\begin{center}%\textbf{\textsection 2. A cryptography system}%\end{center}$1^0.$ In 1975   a public-key cryptography was invented. As a
result, all asymmetric encryption systems appeared later were based
on a certain hard-to-calculate problem. Every such a system led to a
thorough investigation of the problem providing its security.   The
RSA  [39]  motivated the study of integer  factorization, and the
Diffie--Hellman protocols  and ElGamal cryptosystems  [37]  drew
attention to the discrete logarithm problem. This led to the
algorithms such as the Pollard $\rho$- and $\chi$-methods, the
general sieve method for a number field, etc., which deepened our
understanding of these problems and made it possible to solve them
considerably faster than the authors of these systems anticipated.
However, it is not known whether the discrete logarithm or the
factorization problem belongs to the class of $NP$-complete
problems, i.e., the problems which are considered to be
computationally hard. Moreover, for these problems, there are
algorithms running in polynomial time on quantum computers. All this
motivates a further search for new computationally hard problems,
which could be used for constructing encryption systems.

To construct a pairing-based encryption system in the general case,
we need two groups and an encryption map sending a pair of elements
of one group to an element in the other group. The elements of the
first group are messages,   the elements of the second group are
encrypted texts, and the closed key is the inverse map.

We describe this method formally.
 Let $G_1$ and $G_2$ be given groups of a prime order $q$, and let
$
e:G_1 \times G_1 \longrightarrow G_2
$
be a given map.
We denote the elements of  $G_1$ by capitals $P$ and $ Q$ and assume that  $aP = \underbrace{P + P + \dots + P}_{a}$. Then
the maps that can be used effectively for constructing cryptosystems have the following properties:
%\begin{itemize}
1. Bilinearity: $ \forall P, Q \in G_1~~~ \forall a, b \in \mathbb
N^+\qquad e(aP, bQ) = e(P, Q)^{ab}.
$
2. Nondegeneracy: $ P \not= 0 \Rightarrow e(P, P) \not= 1.
$
3. Computability: there must exist an effective algorithm for
computing $e$.
%\end{itemize}
There are two well-known examples of maps satisfying these properties, namely, the pairings of Weil and Tate.
 The cryptosystems mentioned above are based on these pairings. The problem that a malefactor have to solve to break the encryption is obviously the discrete logarithm problem,
  i.e.,  for given $P$ and $Q$  find $a$ such that $Q = aP$.  For a special choice of the groups $G_1$ and $G_2$, it may happen that there are no known algorithms for this problem better than the complete sorting.
   It is clear that it is not harder to solve the discrete logarithm problem in $G_1$ than in $G_2$. Let $e(P, Q) = e(P, aP) = e(P, P)^a$. Then $P' = e(P, P)$ and $ Q' = e(P, Q)$, and $a$ can be found in the group
   $G_2$ as $\log_{P'}(Q')$. The Diffie--Hellman problem  (Decisional Diffie--Hellman or DDH) in a group is computationally easy. The DDH problem consists in distinguishing two tuples $<P, aP, bP, C=cP>$ and $<P, aP, bP, C=abP>$ for unknown $a$ and $b$. Indeed, if   calculating $v_1 = <aP, bP>$ and $v_2=<P, C>$, we obtain that $v_1=v_2$, then the given tuple belongs to the type
 $$
 <P, aP, bP, abP>: e(aP, bP)=e(P, P)^{ab}=e(P, abP)=e(P, C).
 $$ Thus, if the mapping $e$ is known, then the solution of the  DDH problem needs less complexity.

 \subsection{Pairings and  Wieferich numbers}% \begin{center}%\textbf{Pairings and  Wieferich numbers}%\end{center}\begin{itemize}
\item[*] $p $ is an odd  prime;
\item[*] $\mathbb{N}^+$ is the additive semigroup of positive integers;
\item[*] $\mathbb{Z}^{(p)} = \mathbb{Z}^*_{(p)} \cap \mathbb{Z}$ is the multiplicative semigroup of positive integers prime to $p$  (here $\mathbb{Z}^*_{(p)}$ is the group of invertible elements of the ring of  rational $p$-integers);
\item[*] $l(a) = \frac{1}{p}\log a^{p-1}, a \in \mathbb{Z}^{(p)}$ is the function inverse to the Artin--Hasse function. From the properties of the logarithm, it follows that
\begin{equation}
l(ab) =\frac{1}{p}\log (ab)^{p-1} = \frac{1}{p}\log a^{p-1} +
\frac{1}{p}\log b^{p-1} =  l(a) + l(b), a,b \in \mathbb{Z}^{(p)}.
\end{equation}
\end{itemize}{\bf Definition.} Let $p$ be a prime. A number $a$ prime to $p$ is
called Wieferich if
%\begin{equation}$a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \mod p^2.
%\end{equation}
$ Otherwise,
 $a$ is called anti-Wieferich, i.e.,  $a$  is  anti-Wieferich if
%\begin{equation}$a^{p-1} \not\equiv 1 \mod p^2.
%\end{equation}
$\begin{lemma}
If $a \equiv b \mod p^2$, then $l(a) \equiv l(b) \mod p$.
\end{lemma}\textbf{Proof.} Let $a = b + p^2k$. Then
$$l(a) = l(b + p^2k) = \frac{1}{p}\log ((b + p^2k)^{p-1}) = \frac{1}{p} \log(1 + \frac{(b+p^2k)^{p-1}-1}{p}p) \equiv
$$$$
 \equiv \frac{(b+p^2k)^{p-1}-1}{p} \equiv \frac{b^{p-1}-1}{p} \equiv l(b) \mod p.
 % ~~~~~~~~~\vartriangleleft
$$\Endproof{\bf Definition.} We will use the following bilinear pairing arising
in arithmetic geometry:
$
<~,~>_p: \mathbb{Z}^{(p)} \times \mathbb{N}^+ \longrightarrow
\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}, \quad <a,n>_p=l(a)n \mod p.
$\begin{lemma}
The pairing $<~,~>_p$ is bilinear and nondegenerate in the first
argument for the numbers that are not Wieferich (i.e., that are
anti-Wiefeerich).
\end{lemma}\textbf{Proof.} 1) The linearity in the first argument follows from
equation (3). The linearity in the second argument is obvious.

 2)
Nondegeneracy.  First, we check that if $a$ is not Wieferich, then $
l(a)\not\equiv 0\mod p. $ Indeed,
$$
l(a) = \frac{1}{p} \log a^{p-1} = \frac{1}{p} \log \left(1+ \frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}\right) =
$$$$
= \frac{1}{p} \left( \frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}p -
\left(\frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}p\right)^2 + \dots \right) \equiv
\frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p} \not\equiv 0 \mod p.
$$
Therefore, the congruence
$
l(a)n \equiv 1 \mod p
$
has a solution.
Hence,
\begin{equation}
<a,n>_p=1.
\end{equation}%~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~$\vartriangleleft$\Endproof\begin{lemma}
If $a \equiv b \mod p^2$, then
%\begin{equation}
$<a,n>_p=<b,n>_p.
%\end{equation}
$
\end{lemma}\textbf{Proof.} From Lemma 1, it follows that $l(a) \equiv l(b) \mod
p$. Then equality of the lemma follows directly from
definition.
%~$\vartriangleleft$.\Endproof\begin{lemma}
Let $p, q_1, q_2, \dots, q_r  $ be distinct primes. Then there is an
integer $c$ that is anti-Wieferich for  $p$ and Wieferich for $q_1,
q_2, \dots, q_r$.
\end{lemma}\textbf{Proof.} Let $p$ and $q_1, \dots, q_r -$ are distinct odd
primes.  Find an integer $t, t\not\equiv 0, -p \mod p_i$, that for
any $i$, and $t \not\equiv 0 \mod p$(this can be done by the
Chinese remainder theorem). Let $P = q_1...q_r$. Then:
\begin{itemize}
\item[a)] numbers $a = t^P$ and $a = (t+p)^P$ are Wieferich for any $q_i$;
\item[b)] at least jne of these numbers will be anti-Wieferich for $p$.
\end{itemize}
Indeed, to prove that $a)$ it is enough to note that $P(q_i - 1)$ is divided into $q_i(q_i - 1) = \phi (q_i^2)$ and use the Eulers theorem:
$
a^{q_i-1} = t^{P(q_i-1)}\equiv \mod q_i^2.
$
To prove $b)$ assume that both numbers are Wieferich for $p$. Then
$$
1 \equiv (t+p)^{P(p-1)} = t^{P(p-1)}+P(p-1)t^{P(p-1)-1}\equiv 1 - Pt^{(p-1)-1}p \mod p^2,
$$
whence $Pt^{P(p-1)-1}\equiv 0 \mod p$ -
contradiction.

 Now, formula (1) and the definition of the pairing imply

<a, n> = l(a)n \equiv \frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}n \mod p.
$$
Since $\dfrac{a^{p-1}-1}{p} \not\equiv 0 \mod p$, the congruence has
a unique solution $n$.

We prove one more statement, which will be used in the construction
of the cryptosystem and is crucial in the deciphering of
information.

\begin{lemma}If $a \equiv b \mod p^2$, then $l(a) \equiv l(b) \mod
p$.

l(b) \equiv \frac{b^{p-1}-1}{p} = \frac{(a+p^2c)^{p-1}-1}{p} \equiv \frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}\equiv l(a) \mod p.

%\begin{center}%\textbf{Examples of cryptosystems}\subsection{The first system}% \textit{The first system}%\end{center}
In this case, the groups  $\mathbb{N}_p^{(*)} \times \mathbb{N}^+$
and $\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$  play the roles of the groups $G_1$ and
$G_2$, respectively.

{1. \it Key choice.} Let $p$ and $q$ be primes such that $q < p$,
and let $m = pq$. We choose an  $a \in \mathbb{Z}$ satisfying the
following condition: $ \frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p} \not\equiv  0 \mod p $
and  then find a solution $n\in \mathbb{N}$ to the congruence $
\frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}n \equiv 1 \mod p. $ From that it follows by
Lemma 2 equality (4).
We  take the triple $(q, p, n)$ as a
closed key and the pair $(a, m)$ as an open key.

{2. \it Encryption.} Let $M$ be an information to be encrypted. Then
$M$ must satisfy the inequality $M < \sqrt{m}$. We compute the
cyphertext as follows: $ r = a^M ~\mod{m^2}, $ i.e., $r$ is the
remainder when dividing $a^M$ by $m^2$.

{3. \it Deciphering.} To get the information $M$, we have to
calculate
$
M = \frac{r^{p-1}-1}{p}n ~\pmod p.
${4. \it The proof of correctness.} By assumption, $r \equiv a^M \mod
m^2$. Consequently, $r \equiv a^M \mod p^2$ since $p \mid m$. Hence,
by Lemma 3 and Eq. (6), we obtain
$
<r, n>_p = <a^M, n>_p = M<a, n>_p = M. %~~~~\vartriangleleft
$\Endproof
   When deciphering, we solve the problem in the second group and use the known numbers $n$ and $p$,
   while a malefactor does not know them. It is impossible to find $n$ without knowing $p$, and the search
   for $p$ is a hard-to compute factorization problem. However, knowing $p$, we can easily to obtain $n$ by solving the corresponding congruence.

\subsection{The second system}%\begin{center}%\textit{The second system}%\end{center}
Here, the same groups $ \mathbb{N}_p^{(*)} \times \mathbb{N}^+$  and
$\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ play the roles of $G_1$ and $G_2$,
respectively.

{1. \it Key choice}. Let $m$ be a fixed publicly known number and $s
$ a random number, $2 \le s \le m$. We choose $N = pq_1 \dots
q_{s-1}, q_1,...,q_{s-1}<p, s<p$ and a number  $a $ that is
Wieferich  for all $q_i$ and anti-Wieferich for $p$, i.e.,
$
a^{p-1} \not\equiv 1 \pmod{p^2}, ~~~~~~~~~~~a^{q_i-1} \equiv 1 \mod{q_i^2}.
$
Let $b = \frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}$, and let $n$ is a solution of the congruence
$$
b(1-\frac{1}{2}pb+ \frac{1}{3}p^2b^2 - \dots + \frac{(-1)^{s-1}}{s}p^{s-1}b^{s-1})x \equiv 1 \mod{ p^s}.
$$
The open key is the triple $(m, N, a)$, and the closed key is the
tuple $(s, n; p, q_1, \dots, q_{s-1})$.

{2. \it Ciphering.} Let $M<N$ be the information to be transmitted,
it is clear that $M < p^s$. To obtain a ciphertext, we calculate the
remainder $ r = a^M \mod{N^m}, $ which will be transmitted openly.

{3. \it Deciphering.} We denote by $c$ the fraction
$\frac{r^{p-1}-1}{p}$. To obtain the message $M$, we must calculate
$$
c(1 -\frac{1}{2}pc + \frac{1}{3}p^2c^2- \dots + \frac{(-1)^{s-1}}{s}p^{s-1}c^{s-1} )n \equiv M \mod{p^s}.
$$
Besides the factorization problem for $N$, the problem on the number of prime
factors of $N$ arises. We notice that    most well-known algorithms solving the problem need to check the
 primality after each iteration. An extra difficulty arises to chose among the primes obtained  a number
 for which $a$ is anti-Wieferich. Proof of the correctness of the cryptosystem is similar to the first case,
 only the corresponding lemma should be formulated as follows:
\begin{lemma}
If $a \equiv b \mod p^{s+1},$ then $l(a) \equiv l(b) \mod p^s.$
\end{lemma}\subsection{Electronic signature}%\begin{center}%\textit{Electronic signature}%\end{center}
We want to sign a message $\bar{m} = m_1,... , m_n$. First, we
compute the Hash function
$
h = h(m_1, ... , m_n),
$
which practically cannot be changed without changing the message. Next, we choose a number $a, 1<a<p$ for a publicly known prime $p$ that is not a Wieferich number, i.e.,
$
\frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p} \not\equiv 0 ~\mod  p
$
and compute $n$ such that
$
\frac{a^{p-1}-1}{p}n \equiv 1 ~\mod  p.
$
After that we take  $r = a^h ~\mod{ p^2}$ and generate a signed message,
$
(\bar{m}, r, n)~~~~~~~~ (\text{or}\; (\bar{m}, r))
$
The number $a$ is secret and is stored by us. Now, everyone who knows the parameters $p$
and $n$ associated with our name can check the validity of the signature.
For this, it is necessary to compute the hash function $h(\bar{m})$,
for which it is necessary to check the signature as follows:
$
\frac{r^{p-1}-1}{p}n \equiv h \pmod p.
$
